Persons of Concern

=> Data source: The information about UNHCR's populations of concern for a given year and country of residence and/or origin.
Population type throughout the las 10 years.

By the end of 2018, there were 62M displaced people from all around the world.

the highest population numbers are the refugees and the IDPs. So let's take a closer look to see why.

Internally displaced persons (IDPs) in the last 10 years

Number of Refugees per Origin in 2018

By the end of 2018, most of the Internally Displaced Persons come from two sources: There are almost 7.81M IDPs from Colombia, and 6.18M IDPs from Syria.

Syria hold the record for most IDPs in the last 10 years. At the end of 2018, Syrians continued to be the largest forcibly displaced population, with 13.0 million people living in displacement, including 6,654,000 refugees, 6,184,000 internally displaced people (iDPs) and 140,000 asylum-seekers. Colombians were the second largest group, with 8.0 million forcibly displaced, most of them (98 per cent) inside their country at the end of 2018. -UNHCR Report end 2018.

Altogether, refugees from the top 10 countries of origin accounted for 82 per cent of refugees (16.6 million) in 2018, similar to 2017. As in 2017, over two thirds of the world’s refugees come from just five countries: Syria, Afghanistan, South Sudan, Myanmar and Somalia.

The number of refugees under UnHCR’s mandate is almost double that of 2012 and two thirds come from 5 countries.

The global refugee population stood at 25.9 million at the end of 2018, including 5.5 million Palestinian refugees under UnRwA’s mandate,and is now at the highest level ever recorded. -UnHCR Report end 2018

Population displacement figures at the end of 2018

Knowing where displaced people are and how they are living is as important as knowing who they are when it comes to delivering assistance and protection. UnHCR requests geographically disaggregated data on populations of concern from its office, partners and governments, and classifies locations into urban and rural localities (as well as a various/unknown category, which includes locations that are a mix of urban and rural or where the categorization is unclear). -UnHCR Report end 2018

Additionally, UnHCR collects data on the type of accommodation in which individuals reside, especially for refugee populations. This information is important for efficient policymaking and programme design. Accommodation types are classified as planned/managed camp, self-settled camp, collective centre, reception/transit camp and individual accommodation (private), as well as various/unknown if the information is not known, is unclear or does not fit in any of the other categories. -UnHCR Report end 2018

Sadly, today there is more displaced people around the world than ever before. The UnHCR does whatever it can to help, but the situation is becoming overwhelming.
